title: Changes with the ‚ÄòMise en production‚Äô course
text:
Original project structure
Current project structure
















Original repository architecture
Current repository architecture











The new repository architecture was simplified:

Insted of giving acces to older versions of the app via a ‚Äúdev‚Äù folder in the repository, we used tags which allow us to retrace our steps and at the same time make the application architecture visible in root.
There are no longer a separation between data, preprocessing and application folders. This also enables better visibility and faster understanding of the project.
A unique README now summurises all the application functionnalities and characteristics.




Instead of doing the preprocessing locally on our computers, using the data sets downloaded from kaggle, and then saving the pre processed dataset in Github, we now do the preprocessing as part of the application code using the original data frames in an s3 folder.
We also directly use parquet files to do load and process the data wich saves time and memory. Indeed,



Data set


Minimum loading time - memory






CSV


Parquet


Optimized parquet




Recipes


16 s - 687k Ko


7 s - 174k Ko


6 s - 91963124 bites / 11.5k Ko




recipes_data


65 s - 1 256k Ko


40 s - 986k Ko


36 s - 89245812 bites / 11k Ko



The preprocessing code was adapted to reduce the compute time.




The quality of the code was improved and tested (imports in order, pep8 coding conventions, typing, ‚Ä¶).
More functions were created and put in a unique structured folder. Rather than having them in a unique script we created 2 folders and 6 scripts with different functionality for more visibility.
Load/create the preprocessed dataset when the app is opened for the first time.
External parametrizaion with YAML file: the dataframes related parameters (columns to keep or format, file names) and s3 connexion parameters were externalized.





Created CI tests to continuously test the code quality and run the unit tests + to continuously deploy a Docker image of the app to Dockerhub
Deployed manually via kubernetes
Then created a CD pipeline to deploy automatically via ArgoCD

title: Changes with the ‚ÄòMise en production‚Äô course
text:
The new repository architecture was simplified:

Insted of giving acces to older versions of the app via a ‚Äúdev‚Äù folder in the repository, we used tags which allow us to retrace our steps and at the same time make the application architecture visible in root.
There are no longer a separation between data, preprocessing and application folders. This also enables better visibility and faster understanding of the project.
A unique README now summurises all the application functionnalities and characteristics.

title: Changes with the ‚ÄòMise en production‚Äô course
text:
Instead of doing the preprocessing locally on our computers, using the data sets downloaded from kaggle, and then saving the pre processed dataset in Github, we now do the preprocessing as part of the application code using the original data frames in an s3 folder.
We also directly use parquet files to do load and process the data wich saves time and memory. Indeed,

The preprocessing code was adapted to reduce the compute time.

title: Changes with the ‚ÄòMise en production‚Äô course
text:
The quality of the code was improved and tested (imports in order, pep8 coding conventions, typing, ‚Ä¶).
More functions were created and put in a unique structured folder. Rather than having them in a unique script we created 2 folders and 6 scripts with different functionality for more visibility.
Load/create the preprocessed dataset when the app is opened for the first time.
External parametrizaion with YAML file: the dataframes related parameters (columns to keep or format, file names) and s3 connexion parameters were externalized.

title: Changes with the ‚ÄòMise en production‚Äô course
text:
Created CI tests to continuously test the code quality and run the unit tests + to continuously deploy a Docker image of the app to Dockerhub
Deployed manually via kubernetes
Then created a CD pipeline to deploy automatically via ArgoCD

title: Frigo Vide - Recipe Recommender
text:
View on GitHub

Go to the website


üéØ Project Objective
This project provides a smart recipe recommender system that helps users cook meals with what‚Äôs left in their fridge. The system analyzes ingredients and suggests recipes using natural language queries and data processing pipelines.


üîç Project Features

Search Recipes by ingredients or free-text queries
Data Cleaning & Filtering to ensure high-quality recipe suggestions
Streamlit App for an interactive user experience
Kubernetes Deployment with CI/CD using ArgoCD
Dockerized Pipeline for reproducibility and scalability



üöÄ Technologies Used

Python
Streamlit
Kubernetes (Minikube)
GitHub Actions (CI)
ArgoCD (CD)
Docker
Quarto for documentation



üì¶ Dataset
The dataset contains nutritional and measurement data for thousands of recipes and is preprocessed before being used in the app.


üåê Access the App
You can access the deployed app here: frigo-vide-test1.lab.sspcloud.fr
You can access the GitHub repository here: https://github.com/marie678/Projet-Mise-en-prod-3A.git


üõ†Ô∏è Project Structure
.
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .github/workflows/

‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ requirements.txt
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md


‚úçÔ∏è Authors

Marie Meyer ‚Äì GitHub
No√©mie Guib√© - GitHub

import sweetviz as sv
import pandas as pd

# Generate the Sweetviz report
report = sv.analyze(app[['Name','CookTime', 'PrepTime', 'TotalTime','RecipeCategory','AggregatedRating', 'ReviewCount', 'Calories', 'FatContent',
       'SaturatedFatContent', 'CholesterolContent', 'SodiumContent',
       'CarbohydrateContent', 'FiberContent', 'SugarContent', 'ProteinContent',
       'RecipeServings','CookTime_minutes',
       'PrepTime_minutes', 'TotalTime_minutes', 'TotalTime_cat', 'RecipeType',
       'Beginner_Friendly', 'Vegetarian_Friendly', 'World_Cuisine']])

# Display the report in Jupyter notebook
report.show_html('sweetviz_report.html')
